item.title: Overwatch 2 Reveals Patch Notes for July 24 Update
item.description:
Blizzard has released the patch notes for a Stadium balance hotfix applied to Overwatch 2 on July 24. The patch affects the abilities of four Overwatch 2 heroes: D.Va, Freja, Mei, and Juno. The changes made in the July 24 hotfix are meant to supplement a larger mid-season patch released on July 22, just days before.

The July 22 patch for Overwatch 2 marked the halfway point for Season 17 and brought a number of changes to the game's hero balancing, systems, and maps, namely New Junk City and Suravasa Flashpoint. Heroes D.Va, Freja, Mei, and Juno all received a power-up for one or more of their abilities, as did core Overwatch 2 characters Reinhardt, Winston, Bastion, Hanzo, Junkrat, Widowmaker, and Zenyatta. The update also added Loot Box rewards for players who queue up with friends, with Stadium matches counting twice toward each milestone. With the July 24 hotfix specifically affecting Stadium games, diligent players will want to pay close attention to the recent changes to have an edge on the competition.

Blizzard posted the retail patch notes for the July 24 hotfix balance update, which solely applies to the Overwatch 2 Stadium game mode. Of the four heroes affected by the hotfix, D.Va and Mei had their abilities nerfed, while Freja and Juno both received buffs. The damage D.Va is required to take before automatically firing Micro Missiles with her Defense Matrix has been increased from 100 to 150, and Mei's Slowball will now only decrease enemies' speed by 15% instead of 30%. Freja's Bola Build was strengthened to keep up with her Weapon Power builds by increasing the effectiveness of her Lille Faelde Power and the duration of her So Cooked Power, while the critical hit damage bonus of Juno's Medimaster Power was buffed to a 1.5 multiplier.

None of the changes made in the recent hotfix affect those made in the July 22 patch. Notably absent from the update is a fix for the recently disabled Overwatch 2 map Midtown, which was removed from the map pool in the Unranked and Competitive game modes due to an issue with cars becoming invisible on lower graphics settings. Blizzard has still not provided a timeline for the map's return as of this writing.

With Season 17 at the halfway point, fans have a little over a month left before Season 18 releases on August 26, bringing a brand new support hero to Overwatch 2 . Water-themed rebel Wuyang promises to make waves when he premieres alongside the new season, with Blizzard teasing that the healer/damage hybrid will be difficult to master.

Overwatch 2 July 24 Hotfix Patch Notes

Stadium Updates

TANK

D.Va

Developer Comments: Micro Missile build has been delivering consistently high damage output, often exceeding expectations in both burst and sustained fights. This update tones down its effectiveness slightly to bring it more in line with other build options, while still preserving its core playstyle and impact.

  • Countermeasures - Power
    • Increased damage required to mitigate to 150 (Up from 100).

DAMAGE

Freja

Developer Comments: Freja's Bola Build has been underperforming, especially when comparing to Freja's more dominant Weapon Power builds. We're increasing the power here to add more build variety for Freja.

  • Lille Faelde - Power
    • Increased effectiveness to 40% reduced (Up from 50% reduced).
    • So Cooked - Power
      • Increased duration to 3s (Up from 2s).

Mei

Developer Comments: Slowball has been effective at disrupting enemies, but the slow was a bit too punishing for how easy it was to apply. We’re reducing the slow strength to make it less oppressive while still rewarding accurate shots and smart use of Mei’s secondary fire.

  • Slowball - Power
    • Decreased slow to 15% (Down from 30%).

SUPPORT

Juno

Developer Comments: Medimaster wasn’t quite delivering the payoff expected for a critical-focused builds. This buff increases its crit multiplier to better reward precision and reinforce its role as a high-risk, high-reward option for skilled players.

  • Medimaster - Power
    • Increased critical scalar to 1.5 (Up from 1.25).

Overwatch 2 is an always-on and ever-evolving free-to-play, team-based action game set in an optimistic future, where every match is the ultimate 5v5 battlefield brawl. Power up your railgun and disrupt the battlefield as Sojourn, or yield your axe and command attention as Junker Queen. Battle to take control of a robot and move it toward the enemy base in the new Push Mode. Bring the fight to new destinations across the globe in iconic locations like New York, Rome, Monte Carlo and Rio. Daily challenges and frequent updates mean there is always something new to play.

item.title: 5 PS5 Games to Play This Weekend (July 25 - July 27)
item.description:
The PlayStation 5 's library has grown immensely since the new console launched in 2020, and it's showing no signs of slowing down. New games are released for the PS5 on a regular basis, ensuring that there is constantly something new to play along with the thousands of legacy games readily available on the platform.

While summer is traditionally a slow season for the gaming industry, there have been many noteworthy new PS5 game releases. July 2025 alone has seen its fair share of high-profile PS5 game launches, so owners of Sony's latest home console have plenty of new experiences to check out. The new releases from these past two weeks alone should be enough to entertain any PS5 gamer over this weekend.

This weekend's PS5 game recommendations largely focus on the console's latest releases, with a mix of co-op and single-player games. Those that want to play games online with their friends will find some interesting titles here, while those looking for something to play solo this weekend will find recommendations relevant to their interests as well. From the zany Abiotic Factor to the brutally difficult new Soulslike game Wuchang: Fallen Feathers , here are the five PlayStation 5 games that I recommend fans check out this weekend.

Abiotic Factor

PS5 gamers looking for a fresh co-op experience need look no further than Abiotic Factor . A co-op survival game for up to six players, Abiotic Factor has players exploring an underground facility, collecting resources, fighting monsters, and dealing with all kinds of bizarre interdimensional happenings. With aesthetics inspired by Valve's Half-Life series, Abiotic Factor certainly carves out a unique niche for itself in the survival game genre.

What may make Abiotic Factor even more appealing to PS5 gamers is the fact that the game is readily available to play through PlayStation Plus. Those that are signed up for the Extra or Premium tiers of PS Plus can play Abiotic Factor as much as they want without having to buy the game itself. Abiotic Factor being a day one PS Plus Extra game should make it a lot easier for PS5 gamers to convince their friends to check it out as well.

Death Stranding 2: On the Beach

By this point, it's safe to say that most hardcore Kojima fans on PS5 have already played through Death Stranding 2: On the Beach 's story and have reached the end credits. But beating Death Stranding 2 's story is just the tip of the iceberg. The huge open world game is stuffed full of things for players to do if they want to get 100% completion and earn the Platinum trophy. Whether one spends their time building infrastructure for other Porters to take advantage of or works to complete deliveries themselves, there should still be plenty more to enjoy in Death Stranding 2: On the Beach before putting it back on the shelf.

My Friendly Neighborhood

Imagine a BioShock -style survival-horror game with muppets, and that's what My Friendly Neighborhood is. My Friendly Neighborhood first released on PC in 2023 and earned mostly positive reviews, but the bizarre horror game has now made its way to console. My Friendly Neighborhood 's console launch came out of nowhere, but it has proven to be a pleasant surprise for fans of the genre. And with an average time to beat of only 4.5 hours, My Friendly Neighborhood isn't a major time commitment. PS5 gamers should have plenty of time to not only start My Friendly Neighborhood this weekend, but beat the game as well.

Ready or Not

There is a lot of controversy surrounding Ready or Not and how it was toned down to bring the game to consoles, but it still provides an intense SWAT experience that is otherwise hard to find on PS5. Ready or Not is a throwback to classic SWAT games, with players able to tackle missions solo or in co-op with their friends. Each scenario can be tackled in numerous ways, with players rated based on their performance. The goal is to sweep each map, finding the necessary evidence, saving hostages, and arresting or killing bad guys, depending on what the scenario calls for. As long as one isn't too bothered by the censorship controversy, there is a lot to like about Ready or Not .

Soulslike fans have been eating well these last few years, with a steady string of new releases in the genre to enjoy. Wuchang: Fallen Feathers is the latest Soulslike to throw its hat in the ring, and it's proving to be a hit among genre fans. item.title: How to Get Reinforced Hose in Abiotic Factor
item.description:
Abiotic Factor is filled with a wide range of rare crafting materials and items that the player must find in order to progress through the overrun facility. One of the harder items to locate early on is the Reinforced Hose, which is used in several important recipes, as well as repairing broken Kitchen Stoves. Cooking is hugely important throughout Abiotic Factor, so this will be an item that many players are looking to find. The key to crafting a Reinforced Hose in Abiotic Factor is Steel Cable . With this in mind, we'll show you everything you'll need to craft this important material.

How to Craft a Reinforced Hose in Abiotic Factor

Three Key Materials Needed:

Crafting Reinforced Hoses in Abiotic Factor is not difficult on its own. The real problem comes in locating the primary material required to make it: Steel Cable. If you've noticed in the Kitchen on Level 2, you cannot use the stove because it requires a Reinforced Hose. After scouring the entire first three levels of the facility, you'll realize there are no Reinforced Hoses to be found. Even after you find the basic Hose, the Reinforced Hose will not become available to craft until you find Steel Cable, and you'll have to wait a while before it can be located.

The three key materials you'll need to find to craft the Reinforced Hose are:

  • Steel Cable x1
  • Box of Screws x1
  • Hose x1

To craft the Reinforced Hose, you'll need to use a Powered Crafting Bench.

How to Find a Box of Screws and Hose:

The Hose and Box of Screws will be much easier to find than the Steel Cable. You'll encounter a few of them on Level 3, but you won't need to worry about collecting them at that point, because there is a much easier way to get them once you reach Manufacturing West . Reaching this region will be part of the main story, specifically after you make your way through all three levels of the facility. After you get the cafeteria door open in Abiotic Factor, it'll be about two or three major mission tasks until you are required to reach Manufacturing West.

Once you reach Manufacturing West, you'll want to look for the new wooden crates that are marked with yellow and black stripes. Almost every one of these boxes will contain a Box of Screws and a Hose . These boxes are found all throughout Manufacturing West, and are essentially impossible to miss. Use a blunt weapon, such as a Table Leg, to smash open the boxes and loot the materials.

How to Get Steel Cable in Abiotic Factor

Loot or Trade:

Steel Cable is extremely rare in Abiotic Factor' s earlier sections. In fact, it appears that it cannot be found at all until you reach Manufacturing West . Currently, there appear to be two methods for acquiring Steel Cable. The first is to get lucky and locate a spool somewhere in Manufacturing. The second method is to trade the Blacksmith.

As of writing, we have only found one spool of Steel Cable in Manufacturing West, but it is said that more can be found through deeper exploration of the area, as well as further into the game. However, if you are looking to repair a Kitchen Stove as quickly as possible, or craft one of the many items that require Steel Cable, then you may need to rely on trading to get more than one spool.

Steel Cable Location 1:

The only location we have found so far is in the rooms that you reach if you follow the hallway to the right of the Blacksmith. To locate the Blacksmith, follow the signs to the Garage in Manufacturing West. Make sure to watch out for armed Terrorists. From the garage, walk out into the long corridor that separates the garage from Shipping. Turn and look into the large chamber at the end of the corridor, and you'll see a massive sign that says F.O.R.G.E. – this is where the Blacksmith is located.

If you are standing and facing the Blacksmith, turn right, and you'll see a door you can enter that leads to a long hallway that leads to a storage room. Inside the room, you'll find an Exor that will attack you immediately. Take out the Exor, then search the chamber. Inside, you'll find a single spool of Steel Cable sitting on top of a light green crate.

Trading the Blacksmith for Steel Cable:

When you approach the Blacksmith, you can press Y/Triangle to trade. On the list of items, you'll see Steel Cable is available. If you have found Military Electronics already, you'll see that it costs one Military Electronics for one Steel Cable. If you have not found that item yet, you'll only see a questions mark. Luckily, you won't have to go far to find your first Military Electronics.

In the same chamber where the Steel Cable is located, you'll see a small green military radio. If you destroy the radio, you'll get Military Electronics x1. There are several of these radios around Manufacturing West, so you don't have to worry about trading one if you need Steel Cable.

Military Electronics can also be dropped by terrorists upon death, but it is extremely rare. However, if you run out of radios to smash, it may be your best option.

item.title: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2’s DLC Could Tease One Major KCD3 Twist
item.description:
With its second paid expansion just around the corner, Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 fans have a lot to look forward to. The Legacy of the Forge DLC is the game's second expansion, and although information is scarce at the moment, players are eager to be able to build a Kuttenburg forge from the ground up. The DLC is ripe with opportunities, offering a great chance to reflect on the past, since Henry’s adoptive father, Martin, was also a blacksmith. However, perhaps reflecting on the past isn't the only thing this DLC can achieve.

Legacy of The Forge’s arrival in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 seems like the ideal opportunity to explore the past through Henry’s eyes. However, the element of surprise can rest in the DLC’s capacity to look forward as well. Although Kingdom Come: Deliverance 3 is still far off, the early groundwork laid now can significantly influence the narrative, with even the smallest nuggets of information causing massive ripples of excitement and a boom in fan theories.

Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 stays on course towards delivering hefty DLC content after the additions of Brushes with Death, the perfect opportunity for foreshadowing what storm will be brewing in the next installment. Most importantly, the upcoming Legacy of the Forge DLC might lay the perfect grounds for one piece of information that could fuel some of the major conflicts that await Henry of Skalitz.

Laying Down the Foundation for Kingdom Come: Deliverance 3

The wishlist for Kingdom Come: Deliverance 3 is long and brimming with potential. With that wishlist comes a lot of speculation about what the central conflict may entail for players. With Bohemia’s succession somewhat at rest, the struggle between Wenceslas and Sigismund may be an old formula that could grow stale for players seeking something fresh.

Among the most popular theories is one that centers on the Hussite Wars, a pivotal period in Bohemia's history closely following the events of KCD and KCD2 . And if the game actually does pivot into that period of significant civil strife, then that means that Henry’s posse may face significant challenges.

All Eyes on Hans Capon

The young Lord Hans Capon players met in KCD is inspired by a real-world historical figure, Jan Ptacek. The Kingdom Come: Deliverance games have reimagined him as a 20-year-old man who is best friends with Kingdom Come: Deliverance protagonist Henry. However, this reimagination has followed a similar political beat to the real Jan Ptacek’s life, including his alliance during the conflict between Sigismund and Wenceslaus. If Kingdom Come: Deliverance 3 takes place during the Hussite Wars, then a slightly matured Hans could declare his loyalty to the League of Lords against the Hussites. While this is just a fact of Bohemian history, the fictional version of the tale will likely put Henry to the test.

Jan Zizka: The Other Side of History

If Hans Capon represents one side of Bohemia’s future, Jan Zizka represents the other. A military powerhouse and devout Hussite, Zizka would go on to lead reformist forces across the Holy Roman Empire in a bloody and transformational civil war. He’s also a figure of deep moral conviction: one whose cause may appeal to Henry’s sense of justice. With his introduction in KCD2 , KCD3’s setting would be incomplete without him, even if it pivots away from the Hussite war. However, since it is a likely route for the franchise, the split between Zizka and Capon could mark the beginning of Henry’s most difficult dilemma yet.

Henry Might Stand Between Brotherhood and Belief in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 3

As Kingdom Come’ s story inches toward the Hussite Wars, Henry’s future may hinge not just on politics, but on personal bonds. Henry’s deep loyalty to Hans Capon drives him to stand by him at every moment; he’s loyal enough to romance Hans in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 if the player so chooses. But Jan Zizka represents an entirely different path: one that appeals to Henry’s values, his sense of justice, and possibly a new kind of brotherhood forged in fire. Since Henry bonded with Zizka on the battlefield, too, the stage is set for a devastating choice between two people who have shaped him.

A DLC Ripe for Stage Setting

KCD2 's Legacy of the Forge doesn’t just offer a chance at a nostalgic return to blacksmithing for Henry. It could also quietly set the table for Kingdom Come: Deliverance 3 ’s most compelling conflict. Whether through new characters, subtle political foreshadowing, or expanding Henry’s relationships with those around him, the DLC could seed the emotional tension that will one day erupt into a full-blown civil war. If Warhorse wants to give fans a glimpse of the storm to come, it would be best to strike when the iron is hot.

item.title: WoW Mists Of Pandaria: 7 Most Important Locations To Visit As Soon As Possible
item.description:
Summary

  • Important locations like Dawn's Blossom offer training and transportation hubs for faster leveling.
  • Halfhill is a bustling town for rep grinding and learning cooking recipes.
  • Visit Shado-Pan Monastery for raids and attunement quests for max-level characters.

Formerly hidden by a thick fog, the World of Warcraft: Mists of Pandaria have lifted to reveal the game's newest continent. There's a lot to see and do in Pandaria as characters grind to the new level cap of 90, but several locations are more important than others , and players should try to reach these places as soon as possible.

Some of these places are cities that provide high-level training and transportation, while others include dungeons and important quest hubs. For faster leveling, better gear for future raids, and professional training, these are the most important places to visit in Pandaria.

7 Dawn's Blossom

A Transport And Trade Hub

  • Find several profession trainers and traders here.

Dawn's Blossom is one of the first major cities that players find in Pandaria, assuming they follow the questline that starts with their faction discovering the continent. It's also in the Jade Forest, but more centrally located southeast of the original crash and battle sites.

The quest chain that includes the lessons of Loremaster Cho leads to this location, where players can pick up a few other side quests while changing their hearthstones and getting repairs. Several trainers are also located here, which might be the most important feature of all.

6 Halfhill

Home Of The Tillers

  • Visit this village for training and rep grinding.

The small town of Halfhill, found in the central fields of the Valley of the Four Winds, is surprisingly active. The main market is a bustling hub of farmers, vendors, and most importantly, trainers. Characters come here to grind rep with the Tillers, one of the new Factions introduced in the expansion, and learn level 90 Cooking recipes.

The Tailoring trainer is also nearby, in a little village called the Silken Fields just southeast of Halfhill, and he has a few quests for those interested in finding art of one of Pandaria's signature products. The Stormsnout Brewery, one of the new dungeons, is just down the road to the southwest.

5 Temple Of The Jade Serpent

The First Instance Most Players Find

  • Connected to a quest chain that leads south from Dawn's Blossom

The saga of the Jade Serpent begins well before the player reaches the Tem ple of the Jade Serpent . A series of quests, some of which involve our friend Lorewalker Cho, lead south to not only the temple but also locations like The Aboretum and Serpent's Heart.

Following the questline to the Temple reveals more of the legend and lore of Pandaria, including several temples and their animal spirits scattered throughout the land. Players will continue this journey in the Karasang Wilds to the southwest, where they embark on a similar rescue mission at the Temple of the Red Crane.

4 Stormstout Brewery

A New And Exciting Dungeon

  • Help Chen and Li Li recover and restore the brewery.

Bolo the Kegmender in Dawn's Blossom has an interesting story to tell, and it's the start of a quest chain that the player can follow into the Valley of the Four Winds and eventually to the Stormsnout Brewery . Players can still complete the dungeon even if they haven't done the whole quest chain, but this way, they can follow the saga of the family brewery through several generations.

As one of the three dungeons on the continent, players should visit this location as soon as possible to continue upgrading their gear and leveling up. The Temple of the Jade Serpent is a decent starter dungeon, and that progression continues with the Stormstout Brewery.

3 Nesingwary's Safari

An Oasis In The Karasang Wilds

  • Some familiar faces in the wilderness.

Every new continent means a new branch of Nesingwary's Safari, and they have a quaint little camp in the central part of the Valley of the Four Winds, near the southern border with the Karasang Wilds. Players should also note that there's an easy road leading down and south to the Wilds just west of this location.

There's a Skinning trainer located here, Mr. Pleeb the Taxidermist, which is convenient to have if the player is hunting the animals associated with the Nesingwary quest chain and are leveling the profession. The Gnome, Sally Fizzlefury, can help players with Zen Mastery engineering, and there's even a vendor to help lighten the load so they can carry more loot.

2 Mogu'shan Palace

Two Moons And Seven Stars

  • Horde and Alliance HQs.

Mogu'shan Palace itself is home to a raid and a dungeon, but that's not the only thing that draws players to this central location in the Vale of Eternal Blossoms. Unlike previous expansions, which featured neutral cities such as Shattrath and Dalaran, the Alliance and Horde factions now have separate cities on either side of the palace.

The Shrine of Seven Stars is the home to the Alliance, while the Horde claims the Shrine of Two Moons as their base of operations in Pandaria. This is also where some of the max-level trainers can be found when characters reach 90, such as the faction-specific Flight Masters.

1 Shado-Pan Monastery

A Dungeon And A Raid

  • The place to be for max-level characters.

Shando-Pan Monastery ​​​​​​is a cold and treacherous zone that is only open to characters level 87 or higher, but most will be pushing to get there as fast as possible to take part in the expansion's latest raid. It's not just the raid itself, but the associated quests that have to be completed to gain entry; all the Shado-Pan quests in the Kul Li Summit must be completed to be attuned for the raid.

There's also a selection of daily quests for those who want to grind rep with one of Pandaria's most mysterious and powerful factions. The Shado-Pan share some powerful enchanting recipes with their friends, and also offer them a mount and max-level gear when their trust is well-earned.

World of Warcraft: Mists of Pandaria
